page.title: 04TWINEHAM C.E. SCHOOL(cont'd)
page.content: The school is situated in pleasant rural surroundings.The name Twineham means the place of two streams, "Ham" means homestead, manor or river meadow In the 13th century it was called Twyne and in the 16th, Twynym. The school is situated between the Church and the Rectory. There was a school in Twineham on another site in 1716 with 16 pupils. There were 2 day schools and 1 Sunday school in Twineham before 1864, when the rector was given Â£250 for a new school. The school is built of flint and brick. The roof is tiled, and the roof supports are made from old ships' timbers. The school was altered in 1964 and now has 2 class_ rooms in the main building. 2 sets of toilets, boy's and girl's, a staffroom /office and a kitchen servery are joined to the main building.A mobile hutted classroom is built to the rear.
